facts.text: This is Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 315 of 1954 under article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 315 of 1954. Petition under article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by MEHR CHAND MAHAJAN C.J. on October 21, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. October 2 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MEHR CHAND MAHAJAN C.J.-

facts.text: Petitioner is a resident of Akola in the State of Madhya Pradesh and carries on business in oil mills, banking, money lending, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in this matter is a resident of Akola in the State of Madhya Pradesh and carries on business in various lines, i.e., oil mills, banking, money lending, etc.

facts.text: It is alleged that during the war years petitioner made huge profits but evaded payment of tax.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that during the war years he made huge profits but evaded payment of tax.

facts.text: In 1948, Central Government referred petitioner's case to Investigation Commission under section 5(1) of Taxation on Income Investigation Commission Act, 1947, for profits from January 1, 1939 to December 31, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1948 the Central Government, acting under section 5 1  of the Taxation on Income  Investigation Commission  Act, 1947, referred his case to the Investigation Commission for investigation and report, in respect of the profits made by him during the period companymencing with 1st of January, 1939, and ending on 31st of December, 1947.

facts.text: Commission reported on February 28, 1951 that petitioner's concealed income was Rs. 27,25,363 and tax payable Rs. 18,44,949.

anchor.surface_text: The Commission, after investigation, reported on the 28th of February, 1951, that the income of the petitioner companycealed and withheld from taxation was in the sum of Rs. 27,25,363 and the tax payable by him amounted to Rs. 18,44,949.

facts.text: During pendency of investigation, petitioner applied for settlement under section 8-A of Act XXX of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the investigation the peti- tioner applied for settlement under the provisions of section 8-A of Act XXX of 1947.

facts.text: Commission forwarded settlement application with report to Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: This application was forwarded along with the report by the Commission to the Central Government.

facts.text: Petitioner proposed in settlement to pay Rs. 18,44,949 in installments: Rs. 3,44,949 by 25-6-1951, Rs. 5,00,000 by 25-3-1952, Rs. 5,00,000 by 25-3-1953, Rs. 5,00,000 by 25-3-1954, with credit for Rs. 32,034-4-6 already paid.

anchor.surface_text: In the settlement application the applicant proposed that he was prepared to pay the sum of RE. 18,44,949 as under On or before 25-6-1951--Rs. 3,44,949 On or before 25-3-1952-- Rs. 5,00,000 On or before 25-3-1953--Rs. 5,00,0000 On or before 25-3-1954--Rs. 5000,000 and that, he be given credit for a sum of Rs, 32,034-4.6 already paid by him,

facts.text: Central Government accepted the settlement proposal.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government accepted this proposal and the claim for evaded income-tax was thus finally settled by mutual agreement.

facts.text: Petitioner requested and was granted extensions of time to pay installments from time to time.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, subsequently, asked for more time to pay these instalments and this was, also granted from time to time.

facts.text: Petitioner paid total sum of about Rs. 14,00,000 from July 16, 1951 to April 10, 1954 towards the liability.

anchor.surface_text: Commencing from 16th of July, 1951, ,and till the 10th April, 1954. the petitioner paid a total sum of about Rs. 14,00,000 towards discharge of the liability voluntarily agreed to by him on account of the tax evaded.

facts.text: Rs. 4,50,000 remains due payable in installments up to March 25, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: A sum of Rs. 4,50,000 still remains due and is payable in instalments up to the 25th of March, 1955.

facts.text: Settlement term: petitioner undertook not to transfer, mortgage, charge, alienate or encumber properties except with Commissioner of Income-tax permission and for payment of tax.

anchor.surface_text: By one of the terms of the settlement the petitioner undertook number to transfer, mortgage, charge or alienate or encumber in any manner whatsoever any of his movable or immovable properties, barring stock-intrade of-the business, except with the permission of the Commissioner of Income-tax and except for the purpose of the payment of the tax due under the settlement.

facts.text: In June 1954, after Suraj Mal Mohta v. A. V. Visvanatha Sastri decision, petitioner filed this petition under article 32.

anchor.surface_text: In June, 1954, after the decision by this Court of Suraj Mal Mohta v. A. V. Visvanatha Sastri and Another 1 , the petitioner preferred this petition under the provisions of article 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: Petitioner alleges proceedings under the Act imposed liability of Rs. 18,44,949 and led to payment of Rs. 13,99,175, claiming them illegal, ultra vires, void.

anchor.surface_text: alleging that he had been advised that the entire proceedings under the Act which had resulted in the imposition upon him of a liability of Rs. 18,44,949 and in the payment already made of an aggregate amount of Rs. 13,99,175 were wholly illegal, ultra vires, void and unconstitutional

facts.text: Petitioner claims Income-tax authorities not entitled to recover Rs. 4,50,000.

anchor.surface_text: and that the Income-tax authorities were number legally entitled to recover the amount of Rs. 4,50,000 from him.

facts.text: Petition prays for writ quashing proceedings, orders, restraining further action, restoration of Rs. 13,99,715-10-6 with 6% interest, restrain recovery of Rs. 4,50,000.

anchor.surface_text: In the companycluding paragraph of the petition it was prayed that an appropriate writ or direction be issued quashing the entire proceedings, and all orders passed under the Act by the Central Government and the respondent Commission, and restraining them from taking any proceedings whatsoever under the Act against the petitioner. It was further prayed that a direction be issued for restoration to the petitioner of a sum of Rs. 13,99,715-10-6 with interest at 6 per cent and that the respondents be further restrained from taking any action against the petitioner for the recovery of the sum of Rs. 4,50,000 with interest.

facts.text: Court finds petition misconceived as recovery based on settlement proposed by petitioner and accepted by Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment this petition is wholly misconceived. Whatever tax the petitioner has already paid, or whatever is still recoverable from him, is being recovered on the basis of the settlement proposed by him and accepted by the Central Government.

facts.text: No assessment made under Income-tax Act procedure due to settlement request.

anchor.surface_text: Because of his request for a settlement numberassessment was made against him by following the whole of the procedure of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Petitioner must establish settlement improperly procured to claim relief under article 32.

anchor.surface_text: In this situation unless and until the petitioner can establish that his companysent was improperly procured and that he is number bound thereby he cannot companyplain that any of his fundamental rights has been companytravened for which he can claim relief under article 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Article 32 not for relief against voluntary actions; remedy lies elsewhere.

anchor.surface_text: Article 32 of the Constitution is number intended for relief against the I voluntary actions of a person. His remedy, if any, lies in other appropriate proceedings.

facts.text: Petitioner contends settlement under pressure of Act's coercive machinery, not binding.

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the petitioner companytended that apparently the application for a settlement seems to have been made under the pressure of circumstances and in view of the companyrcive machinery of Act XXX of 1947 and the settlement arrived in such circumstances was number binding and companyld number, be enforced.

facts.text: Such contention cannot be raised under article 32; forum elsewhere.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever be the merits of such a companytention, it obviously cannot be raised in an application made under the provisions of article 32 of the Constitution. The forum for investigating such allegations is elsewhere.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever tax the petitioner has already paid, or whatever is still recoverable from him, is being recovered on the basis of the settlement proposed by him and accepted by the Central Government. Because of his request for a settlement no assessment was made against him by following the whole of the procedure of the Income-tax Act. In this situation unless and until the petitioner can establish that his consent was improperly procured and that he is not bound thereby he cannot complain that any of his fundamental rights has been contravened for which he can claim relief under article 32 of the Constitution.

concepts.interpretation: Voluntary settlement binds the petitioner and precludes challenge to underlying proceedings under Article 32 unless shown to be improperly procured; remedy elsewhere.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: s number bound thereby he cannot companyplain that any of his fundamental rights has been companytravened for which he can claim relief under article

concepts.unlisted_label: Binding Nature of Voluntary Tax Settlement
concepts.unlisted_description: Agreement proposed by assessee and accepted by government supersedes statutory proceedings for constitutional challenge purposes.

issues.text: Whether sections 5, 6, 7 and 8 of Act XXX of 1947 were invalid and ultra vires in so far as they contravene the provisions of articles 14, 19(1)(f) and 31 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: sections 5, 6, 7 and 8 of Act XXX of 1947 were invalid and ultra vires in so far as they contravene the provisions of articles 14, 19 1   f  and 31 of the Constitution and that under the Act

issues.text: Whether the petitioner can complain that any of his fundamental rights has been contravened for which he can claim relief under article 32 of the Constitution given that recovery is on the basis of the settlement proposed by him and accepted by the Central Government unless his consent was improperly procured

anchor.surface_text: Whatever tax the petitioner has already paid, or whatever is still recoverable from him, is being recovered on the basis of the settlement proposed by him and accepted by the Central Government. Because of his request for a settlement no assessment was made against him by following the whole of the procedure of the Income-tax Act. In this situation unless and until the petitioner can establish that his consent was improperly procured and that he is not bound thereby he cannot complain that any of his fundamental rights has been contravened for which he can claim relief under article 32 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether article 32 of the Constitution is intended for relief against the voluntary actions of a person

anchor.surface_text: Article 32 of the Constitution is not intended for relief against the voluntary actions of a person. His remedy, if any, lies in other appropriate proceedings. The learned counsel for the petitioner contended that apparently the application for a settlement seems to have been made under the pressure of circumstances and in view of the coercive machinery of Act XXX of 1947 and the settlement arrived in such circumstances was not binding and could not, be enforced.

issues.text: Whether the application for a settlement seems to have been made under the pressure of circumstances and in view of the coercive machinery of Act XXX of 1947 such that the settlement arrived in such circumstances was not binding and could not be enforced

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the petitioner contended that apparently the application for a settlement seems to have been made under the pressure of circumstances and in view of the coercive machinery of Act XXX of 1947 and the settlement arrived in such circumstances was not binding and could not, be enforced. Whatever be the merits of such a contention, it obviously cannot be raised in an application made under the provisions of article 32 of the Constitution.
